item.title: The First Interview
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded:
Bloomberg Financial Software Engineer intern position, failed the phone interview. Shouldn't be, but still reasonable. The interviewer probably didn't know what I'm talking about. And from the very beginning, he was more anxious than me. First question, 1 million numbers ranged from 1 to 100,0000. Find the number that appears most. Linear programming, pretty easy one. Second question, 10 million numbers ranged from 1 to 2^32. Find the number that appears most. Well,Â  I should have answered sort the input and then do the counting. But I just thought using binary search tree is a better option, so long as there are a fixed number of different integers in the input string. In that case, searching the nodes representing that integer will take constant time. However, you couldn't express it clear enough. At least you were not sure if it is a red-black tree or a binary search tree. You were not sure what you were talking about. And the interviewer thought you were some sort of blabbing. Third question, how to do auto-correct spelling errors like "New YYork" to "New York", given a list of valid city names. My answer was using dynamic programming to find the Longest Common Substring of the two strings. Then remove the LCS from both strings and find the LCS again. Repeat 4 times (4 is an arbitrary number here). Then use the "sum of length of all LCSs * 2 / sum of the length of the two strings" -- the "matching percentage" to measure how well the two string math. I couldn't express it very clearly in such a short time, and he didn't know what I was talking about. At last, "Why Bloomberg?" I just told him I was not that into engineering stuff and wanted to do math modeling and finance. This is an engineering position, dude. Saying this means you don't fit. How could anyone hire you if you told them you don't love the job? I really don't hate that, but you really should avoid talking about this. In the interview, he kept telling me that I should follow my interest. Kind of weird, rejecting me for not dragging me into hell? I bet not, or maybe? What's the moral of the story?
  • Pay attention to the detail. As an engineering major, paying attention to detail is very important. As to talking, you should explain your idea carefully and especially detail.
  • Speak less, but clear. You are a foreigner and you can't express your idea that clear to others. So speak less, but make sure your audience understand what you are talking about.
  • Don't play the fancies things. This is really ironic, your resume says "full of common sense" and "good communication skills". Showing how smart you are by playing the fancy things is not a good idea. If there's an appropriate but not fancy solution, use it.
  • Act like a man, not a boy. You speak too fast and you don't care what your audience think about. How could you become entrepreneur with such a talking style?
  • Be more mature. You don't like Google and Microsoft? Really? No? But why you said that to the interviewer? That shows you are so arrogant and can't be a good team member, especially in an engineering team.
  • It's OK to be quite for some time in a interview. Think carefully about the question and stop talking all the time! Generalize your solution then tell your interviewer about it.
To sum up, don't act like a nerd.

item.title: Exercise 5 Knowing your reader
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded:
Your beloved Uncle Wilfred has died at the ripe age of 98. During his lifetime, he attended Youngblood Academy, served in the navy, married Aunt Sylvie, had three children--Ella, Peter, and David--and taught high school science. How and how much of this information would you convey to the following audiences.
1. An obituary in the local paper?
Wilfred Zong, former navy commander and a dedicated high school teacher, died Monday at the age of 98.
Mr. Zong died at his home in San Bruno, California, said his life long companion and wife, Sylvie Zong.
Mr. Zong fulfilledÂ his responsibility as a US citizen: He served for his country as a Navy commander when his country needs him; he fedÂ services back to his community in San Bruno as a dedicated high school science teacher.
Wilfred Zong was born in 1948, Baoding City, Hebei, China. At the age of 5, ZongÂ and his family moved to California, United States. In his early years, Zong attended Youngblood Academy for science study. After graduated from Youngblood Academy, Zong joined the US Navy at 1965 during the Vietnam War.
After the war, Zong returned home andÂ continued his educationÂ by attendingÂ UC Berkeley to studyÂ Physics. After graduated from UC Berkeley, Mr. Zong became a teacher at San Bruno High School, where he taught science for 37 years. Zong is widely loved by his fellow students, and he got a nickname "Sir Newton" for his excellent Â teaching.
Zong married Sylvie, his life long companion at 1977. They had three children Ella, Peter, and David. The Zong family is dedicated to serving their community. They had helped providing financial supports to neighboring children to attend college.
Through his life, Wilfred Zong witnessed the drasticÂ change of ourÂ century. Mr. Zong lived his life as a true citizen, as one of the heroes of our day.
his faithful cousin, Mengqi Zong

item.title: Food, food, food.
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded:
Site construction is much smooth than I expected. I finished the major structure of the site at 3 a.m. Dec. 28th -- 3 days ahead of my schedule. As to the rest of it, let it be a long-term project, and this is the only efficient way to do it. After 15 hours no eating, I decided to go out to get some food.
So most of the fast food restaurants in New York are not 24-7. And trying to buy some fried chicken at 4 a.m. is really not a good idea: closed, closed, closed, closed. Fair enough, if there is no profit, who will do that? That reminds me of the United States Postal Service and the long debates about state-owned enterprise.
Finally, I got some food from a old Mexican woman's food truck at 125 St. 5 o' clock in the morning, everything on the street is still dim, and there is only cold winds blowing the overnight trashes away. This make me wondering why this old woman get up so early. If there is no profit, who will do that? Well, then it should be worthy for her to get up such early in the morning -- I would rather say it is the mid-night. Right, it should be.
Or is it? Is it worthy for at most 20 dollars profits, for a 60 years old woman? And where is your son, old lady?
So, this is life. Maybe she deserve it, or maybe not. I hope this never happens to my parents. Well, can you and will you, in the future? And how could you know if that's not happening right now? A joker on the dark corner of your heart just keeps tormenting you. And those satirizing jokes just look so real.

item.title: Once upon a time at BC
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded:
In the past few days, I have been playing World of Warcraft, the TBC version, on a private server called lastwow.
In general, this server is the best PVP private server I have ever seen (that's why I choose it). And this Euro server is quite different Â from the old server I use to play, more trolling and less goal-oriented. Also, due to people come from different time zones, you can always find players playing at any time. It's kind of interesting to play here.
Leveling up is a bit of pain to me, everything is just a boring repeat to me. However, thanks to the 15 X experience, it only takes 2 days to get to level 70.
Here comes the urban life, endless battlegrounds and endless raids. I spent 14 euro to get two top weapons:Â Hand of the Deceiver and Crux of the Apocalypse. Well, Neilyo 15 is so memorable to me. Â And that's one big reason for me to get back to WoW.
As to the rest of my gears, I tried raiding, but every raid is just one epic fail. Reminds me the time we direct Illidan (due to bugs, you can directly fight Illidan without kill all previous bosses) and watching Illidan get pwned by Akama. At last, I end up getting my every gear from battleground rewards.
Speaking of bg, there are Â a lot of noobs here whoÂ literallyÂ knows nothing about how to play bg. For example, in Arathi Basin, no one is playing defense and everyone is justÂ gatheredÂ up zerging. Kind of fine, but if you are eager about wining the bg and get the gears, then it is reallyÂ annoying. Â Later, I just got used to it and begin to enjoy it, just imagine yourself as a ruthless trouble-maker, pillaging here and there. That's kind of cool. However, when you played it too much, it just got boring. That's inevitable for almost everything.
As to the arenas, lots of good PVP players here. Since I have trouble on getting gears, arena is not that enjoyable to me at most of the times. Well, sometimes it is very funny since with my own gear, I am still able to kill players who have top gears. That's really beautiful.
In total, for the BC version, some are good and some are not. BC time is not as fantastic as I thought since there's less abilities for you to use. Well, good days just stay in the past, and trying to get it back is not a good idea. Better just leave it in your memory.
Well, one good thing about playing at lastwow is that it let me know about ArcEmu, an open source WoW server. I think I will try it later, establishing my own WoW server and also Â trying to learn something about MySQL (I always fancy about that). That's really awesome.
At last, I have to admit that it's bad for my winter break studyingÂ schedule. Now I just finished finished reading lshort. I have to change my old schedule to fit my current situation.
However, I didn't regret about this. If things come natrually, better not resist it, resist your temptation -- it can only become stronger inside you, causing much trouble later. Instead, just embrace it, and everything will be fine later on.
All right, I think that's it. I am mostly bored at the WoW and try to get back on my normal life. Time to learn some Inroduction to Computational Learning Theory.

item.title: Notes works!
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded:
Having been writing down some notes and questions for half a month, I find that totally worth it. I always have trouble on thinking in depth, because it's quite easy for me get lost in thoughts and then totally can't find the way back. I guess that's one of the reasons why I only have random ideas but never made them structural. I trust my instinct. Why I trust it? Because most of the time it used to be one of those thoughts lurking in my mind. I already draw some conclusions about it. I just can't remember it, and those conclusions just may not right... Now, with these notes, I can make it way further forÂ  correcting those false conclusions I made before and make more precise, in depth conclusions. This is really amazing and I am totally shocked. A few days ago, I made some false interpretation about the PAC learning model based on experience. And I thought it was some pretty good one. However, later, I found those interpretation does not sound that right but I didn't know why. If I were thinking those thing only with my mind, I would probably
  • lost my mind on "what if this ... Wait, what about...Â  Damn, where am I?" or "got to go to eat ... burp, burp... Wait, what is the question I have been thinking about" or ..., ..., arr... damn it...
  • have a totally headache;
  • get totally frustrated and think this problem is too complicated to handle;
But now, everything is different. With the notes I made, I can continue my thought easily and make more precise interpretations. In this process, I almost lost my thoughts like ten times. But that's OK, I can easily get back on! This is really awesome! And one of wowcrendor's comments on how did he make those funny videos is exactly what I want to say right now, now I rephrase it:" I scribe, that's very important.Â  I write my idea down and keep thinking about it. Finally I will get some really awesome ideas."

item.title: Do I speak in circles?
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded:
Do I speak in circles?
In a way, I guess. To most of the things and concepts, I never truly master their essence. I may express my partially right (i.e. great potential to have lots of mistakes) ideas by examples, but examples can never express ideas accurately.
What does the confidence level mean? I showed my concern about whether the sample can represent the population. Then I just gave an example "a bad sample can't predict the estimator correctly".
So what does that mean? It just means result from some samples may not work. Then? But in high perspective, when doing large amount of experiments, the particular amount of results proportional to confidence level will work.

item.title: What is the really good thing about writing down your thoughts?
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded:
In software engineering, component reuse will bring a huge improvement on performance and efficiency. That's because people won't have to deal with trivial things like coding quick sort all the time. And remember that writing codes like quick sort one thousand times will not ever improve your skill greatly (This is not Skyrim! And shame on you, Skyrim game designers!). Actually that's why scientist build the computer, they don't have to spend endless time to calculate those equations to get some answer they already know they can get.
I find one thing about Donald Knuth is quite wise: he wrote some basic generic codes and then use them through his entire life. As to me, I can always myself in a situation of wasting time recoding basic algorithms. That's surely not a good experience. If I can build my personal repository, I probably could save 5 years in my life!
And what does all those related to writing down your thoughts? Writing thoughts down means you are actually building your personal thought repository. It's not some kind of show off (remember, NOBODY CARES!). It's about help yourself thinking.
Why can I think further with notes? Because I don't have to waste time thinking those basic ideas like quick sort in coding! And one important thing in thinking is that you can not concentrate that long. If you spend much of your time span thinking something you already know but you can't remember, then you will soon get distracted before you can think some new.
I think this is another way to explain why it is very important to write things down.

item.title: Babbling
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded: I do know things will go pretty bad, but I would never know that I could feel such disappointed about myself. Well, I know, everything will eventually turn out to be OK and I will be fine. Right, it's just a matter of time. But now, you are humiliating yourself and you know it. Going to the office hours and the professor thought you might have missed some of the lectures when you asked him questions. Well, it's better to let others know you are a idiot and then no longer be a idiot than always be a idiot. I just kept telling myself about this. Hey, that's not true! You can learn it by yourself, loser! You are just making excuses, work harder, baddie! Yeah, I might should have done that. Oh, that also looks totally cool: really low keep, the mysterious man, the mysterious and powerful man. Everybody likes it, and I like it, too. You know what? I used to be one. Right, that's absolutely cool.Â  You looks well-behaved, no dumb questions, no harsh feelings. You are the tip-top. You don't always shatter others' self-esteem, but when you do, you do it like a boss. That feels awesome. But, eight years' silence doesn't teach me how to properly treat people. Staying quietly in the classroom not asking any questions does not make me understand what the teacher is trying to say. The no-one-know claim you are trying to crack after class probably has already been proved by some mid-20 century Russian mathematicians: you are going to have a harsh time on it and you don't know it. When you solve it, you would not be able to publish a paper. And on the other hand, you could have learnt this idea in 10 minutes by reading some papers. Yes, your effort is meaningless. You could do it better and you know it. You know you need to communicate. "Well, that might cost me a lot," you just think those things in that way. So yo hesitate, shivering in the shadow of the good-looking past. Let the line haunts wildly in your subconscious: where is your pride? You are the jester and you know how it feels - pride is the last thing you want to give up. All right, then why taking a statistic course you cannot handle and looking like a completely idiot in the classroom? You probably can't get a A. Hey, you are stupid! Yeah, I am talking to you, loser! But you know this is the best way to understand the essence of computer science. If you haven't taken it, you probably can't truly understand those NLP models; and you never will be able to appreciate the beauty of Occam's Razor. Now, you look even more immature than what you used to be when you were 14. Asking stupid geeky questions, sending nonsense emails, spreading funny pictures to all your friends. Nobody cares doesn't mean nobody hates it, OK? You are squeezing humour form yourself!Â  Want some joke? How about "your life"? It's hard to be a geek. And it's hard to become childish. Thinking more and more rationally isn't that cool as you thought about. You can feel your mind is solidifying: your world is falling apart. Connections are being destroyed. And everything there is just white and grey. At last, you know exactly that few people will appreciate what you have done. It simply takes so much efforts to make up your mind -- to give up things that are shiny, to say goodbye to all your friends, to embrace the endless hard working hours. You are going to be alone on the road ahead. You used to be never begging people for help. Because that's the price you can't take. And you would rather give yourself a harsh time than asking people for help. But why are you doing it right now? Just look at you, you changed. Actually, I never changed. I am still the one I use to be. I am still learning things in the harsh way, in a much much more harsh way. I still cherish my dignity, but can only afford the most precious part. Becoming a monkey in the suit some day is just so scary.

item.title: A Lesson of Life
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded: I always thought that love is just for cowards. And I am probably right. Because all those people I have ever seen who rushed into the river of love were just bored of their personal pursuit and only wanted to have some fun. If you can have some fun, then why not? But love is not everything, that's for sure. One day you will get bored of it, just like all other things. I used to think that if I am strong enough, I can live my own life without company. Actually I still think so. I know what I want: the self-perfection and the ultimate answer to everything. And that's almost nothing about love. Newton didn't get married for his entire life, but still did lots of excellent work. Solitude maybe one important reason for his success -- he has more time than anyone else to do what he wants, with his free will. All in all, at least I don't want to be a coward. Attempting to pursue a relationship because I am bored and afraid of the road ahead? That's ridiculous and extremely humiliating to a man with a brave heart. Everyone has to accept the challenge life bestowed him in order to achieve his own goal. That's how this world works. The harder the battle, the sweeter the victory. Well, maybe you are just that selfish. You thought all the girls you have met are just blood suckers who want to bleed you dry. And they came to you simply because they saw your success. Well, I am not that good. But probably, most of the girls I have ever seen are just afraid of dying alone and want some easy money. I bet they never know what love is all about. "Some sort of cool thing to brag about and to post on the social networks?" They probably think so. Come on people, I feel totally bored talking with you. And I really don't want to get stuck with a loser for my entire life and keep feeding her my money. And having suffered my entire day at work, I still have to face your angry face and spend some time to calm you down? I don't want to waste my precious time and emotions on you. I always get things to do and I am really busy. Am I wrong? Actually, most of them are douchebags and blood suckers. Gee, when I was chilling out and minding my own business before I won my respect from my college, you guys are so arrogant. Now, you just turn out to be this humble with no reason? What's wrong with your twisted souls, people? Yeah, I know personal success can change one's opinion, but there's no contradiction with that you guys are assholes. Well, I am really not a believer of love. My parents' marriage seems to be such a pain. And that's purely their own choice! Fact is both of them are not happy for a long time. Still, I am glad I finally relived the situation a little by my small success. That gives them honour and hope. But before that, all I heard are "look at your son, bla bla bla...". It's a situation you definitely want to avoid -- even your parents want to shit in your face. Home may look sweet, but I never really enjoyed staying there. Well, I give my respect to my parents for building up their everything all by themselves. They are generally good people with kind hearts. And it's them who gave me all their life savings to help me pursue my dream. And they did treat me well, though not always. And I was not always a good son. But Mao Zedong is also not a good son. But no one is born to be a good parent. At last, I know that I have to go away, just like what's in the song of Cat Stevens. I just want my freedom. And please everyone, just leave me alone. Coming to the States, I finally got a chance to be absolutely alone. All my old friends are 6000 miles away. Here, no one knows me and no one cares. I thought I could finally truly enjoy what I have been dreaming of, doing whatever I want without being disturbed. But things always turned out to be far away from what I thought them to be. I then realised that I am still a social animal -- I could act awesome while standing in the corner a distance away from the crowd, but can't stay cool without the crowd. I spent so much time checking and rechecking the websites and emails. And it was boring and I knew it. "You are not tough enough", that's what came to my mind. But life is not like sports, you just need to stick to something and the goal is that simple. On the contrary, it's complicated. And inspirations from regression model and the famous game "the Sims" tell me that you can only achieve a great achievement when you are happy -- Ironically, a mental status most people are pursuing for. Wait, I like what I am doing now. Yes, the burden it's a little bit heavy, but still OK to me. Then what happened to me? Why do I feel so anxious, depressed? I was lost at that time, trying to find the answer. Until later I learned it from a girl. "The joy found in solitude, freedom, independence, and even inner spiritual power, is different from the joy stemmed from human bonding, healthy relationship, having a loving family. Both are important, but one cannot substitute for another." That's what she said. A lesson no one ever succeed teaching me through. This is why I am trying to start a relationship with her. Though I am still totally messed with this crazy semester; though waiting and guessing made me can't study at all for days; though self-esteem almost drove me into smashing everything for several times because of the humiliations I never undertook before. It's a challenge, not an escape. And it will benefit you in the long run, though in the short run you are going to suffer. It's a road to learn, not simply for the result. The result doesn't matter that much. Actually all results never matter that much. Just embrace life itself and see what it is going to show you. Welcome to the river of love.

item.title: From Computational Power to Intelligence
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded:
Professor Alexander told me that IBM is doing a long term project aiming at building a cluster as complicated as human brain. This cluster will have as many CPUs as the number of neurons in a human brain.
Well, no one knows what is going to happen when we have such a powerful computer. Maybe all those exponential-time AI algorithms which have been considered useless will turn out to be quite practical. It is just because currently we don't have such a powerful machine. And if we have a machine as powerful as a human brain, then computer can do what human can do. Zing, intelligence!
Actually, I am really not a big fan of this. I always think that there are some philosophical ideas which play a crucial role on intelligence still have not yet been discovered. At least, all state-of-the-art AI algorithms does not look like what our brain works. And how could we assume that we can invent intelligence with such a powerful machine while not knowing how to rule it? Miracle? Not that likely to me.
And this can't explain the irrationality rooted in our way of thinking.Â As human beings, we are not always rational. And who said irrational is a bad thing? Rational is just conventional wisdom. If everyone thinks the world is flat, then thinking world as a round object will be the so-called irrational. Right, the proof of earth as round does require careful observation and accurate reasoning. But I always believe, we get the idea, or that flash, from a sudden irrational thought. A thought breaks the bound of thinking.
Our intelligence is naturally nondeterministic.
I always believe that randomness is closely related to what this world is all about. Personal experience tells me that certainty is not what this world means to be. This even contradicts with the meaning of life -- If your life is certain and you can do nothing about it, then why live?
To me, uncertainty is the meaning of life. Because if life is uncertain, and you know nothing about what is going to happen next, then your life begins making sense. And this uncertainty is not totally out of our control -- we still can choose the main direction. So it is a semi-controllable uncertainty. What is this thing? Probability.
You can set your minds to increase your probability to particular things, but it's hardly can be certain, i.e. a probability of 100%. It's almost like what this world is all about. Think about the idea of regression. Or just think about its origin -- Evolutionism. As a sample unit, you can do whatever you want, but to everything you do, there is a probability. If there is a God, then God just wants to control the mean and the variance of the normal distribution. That is, the mean is what he wants. Too extreme will cause trouble to single sample unit. But if everyone's behaviour changes, that is, mean changes. Then it is a different story. In this way, human evolves. World progresses in a certain but not too certain direction.
This reminds me about quantum computing. The key difference between the normal computing and quantum computing is that quantum computing is naturally random. If you have dealt with randomness on current computers, you will know that real randomness does not exist in current computers. And it's really clumsy to represent randomness and probability on them. But on a quantum computer, it is just that natural.
And that's one reason why quantum computing is this powerful. When dealing with a really complicated problem, using one computer to crack it will be really time consuming. Then why not use lots of computers and let every one guess it? And if the "lots of" is one, then better!
The idea of quantum computing really makes me rethink about what has been described in "The hitch-hikers' guide to the galaxy" -- Earth is a super computer and every human being is a sample unit of the computer. And every human is running a nondeterministic algorithm to compute the ultimate answer to life, universe and everything. Exactly what a quantum computer do.
Why nondeterministic algorithm? Why not a deterministic one?
Because deterministic algorithm is too slow. And if you have a large sample, then with each sample unit runs nondeterministic algorithm will turn out to be much faster.
But only one thing, it seems to be really hard to implement recursion on this model of world. Because human beings have a certain life span. This makes progress slower than it should be.

item.title: Memoryless and memory
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded:
In order to implement "memorylessness", you need to have a memory.
What is memoryless? Current procedure's probability only depends on the current procedure. Why it is called memoryless? Because every time you do this procedure, it seems like the very first one. That is, there's nothing before that (actually, there are things before that). So, you are acting like a guy without memory (can't remember anything ever happened to you).
However, if you don't have a memory, then once you failed, you have to restart over from the very beginning. In this case, the probability not only depends on the current procedure, but also depends on the previous ones. Then it is not memoryless.
On the other hand, if you have a memory, you can act like you are "memoryless". Because every time you fail, you just need to check up your memory and restore the situation one step before the procedure ever happened. In this case, you are truly memoryless!"
That is, by restoring the previous situation using a memory, the probability of the current procedure only depends on the current procedure. And it seems to be the only way for sequential events to be memoryless (I am kind of assuming that "cause and effect" are everywhere).

item.title: Conversation in a Simple Way
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded:
Rule of Thumb: On 95% of the cases, express your idea briefly and easy-to-understand.
1. How to express your idea briefly?
On 68.3% of the cases, your email/text message/talk should be NO more than 70 words, or NO more than 1 paragraph.
On 95.4% of the cases, your email/text message/talk should be NO more than 140 words, or NO more than 2 paragraphs.
2. How to express your idea easy-to-understand?
On 95% of the cases, your email/text message/talk should make sense to 95% of your audience. You should avoid using terms, philosophical ideas,Â unpopular topics, and educational tones (This can irritate your audience in a causal conversation).
3. How could I know it is the situation in the 5%?
If it is possible for you to express your idea briefly and easy-to-understand, then do it. Beat the long, boring and hard-to-understand expression as possible as you can.
If you can't express your idea such intuitively, then you should try remaining silent at the first place. If that is not an appropriate action, then you may want to try a long, complicated expression. This kind of situation is rarer than you think.

item.title: Conversation 101 (Continue Updating)
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded:
0. Simple is good. 1. In causal conversations, nobody wants to be really serious, at least at the very beginning. So beat the serious topics. 2. Telling the truth is not always the best action. Because:
  • Nobody cares about your truth.
  • Nobody wants to hear about the truth even if it is true.
So if you can't say some appropriate words, then don't say. 3. Don't always want to tell other people how hard your time is. First, nobody cares. Second, nobody wants to hear about it. Third, everyone is busy too! It gives other people an impression that you are just a kid who never experienced anything before. And probably they are right. When you look backwards, you will realize that's nothing. See entry #2. 4. If you know nothing about other people's situation, do NOT endlessly talk about your opinion about it. Because your opinion is probably very wrong and you just look like a jerk in other people's eyes. Why not stay humble and try to learn something from others? 5. There's always a reason for a conversation. Better knows what they need. And speak things straight to the point. This makes everyone's life easier. Aimlessly talking somethings is not always a good choice. See entry #2. 6. Your comforting words can't make people feel better about their misfortune if the words can't change the situation. Then what should you do? Don't mention it. Like what our society does. See entry #2. 7. One lesson I learned several years ago about the assumptions of your strategy: You should assume everyone is smart enough and informative enough to know exactly what you are about to do. In other words, don't expect you can cheat people or people will make silly mistakes. To be somewhat specific, lying is what you can't handle, and it can NOT give you benefits in general. 8. Before you say something, ask yourself the following question: Does anyone care? See entry #5. 9. If you help others and others help you, all your life become easier and better. And that's why we need conversations - the simplest way of information exchange. It can satisfy both sides' needs. Since this is the general reason of a conversation, then better help others in a conversation. See entry #5. 10. Text based online chatting sometimes can be pretty messy. Due to the latency of your typing and reply, it's very easy for two people to talk about their own things. So, pay attention to the trends of what they want to talk about and cooperate. See entry #5. 11. Slow down, don't speak that fast. 12. Try to not be that self-centric in a conversation. That is, care about how other people feel. 13. Do not hide your ignorance. Be honest, and proactive when necessary. This means, if your ignorance could prevent you from understanding what others are talking about, then speak it out. Because, if not, you are wasting other person's time. This is consistent with #5. And this is different with #2, but both #2 and #13 are saving other person's time.

item.title: Cleverness and Complexity
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded:
1. Can complicated statement show that a person is clever?
No. If there exists a simple statement, then this person is dumb. Only dumb people are good at making simple things complicated. Smart people are good at making complicated things simple.
2. Then why people always think a person who can state a complicated statement clever?
Beware of the "relativity" here. The word "simple" and "complicated" make sense only when there is a comparison.
People often compare apple with orange. Some topics are easy to explain but some are not. For those not-easy-to-explain topics, one person has to use a more sophisticated statement. In this case, it is complicated. However, note that this "complicated" statement is the simplest statement one person can offer for this not-easy-to-explain topic.
Why he or she looks clever? Because for this topic, most people don't understand! That is, most people can only make a statement for this topic with a complexity of infinity. In contrast, the one who can state a valid but complicated statement is definitely more clever than those people.
But what if some people can make a easy to understand statement? Then those people are the best.
3. So...
Some awful people always try to take advantage of the subtlety between cleverness and complexity. They will try to explain an idea to a outsider as complicated as possible to show that how clever they are. This is really ridiculous. Or I really should say this is evil.
4. What's the moral of the story?
Simple is good.

item.title: Benjamin Rutt's Emacs C Development Tips
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded:
So you are developing in C (or C++, or java) in emacs. This web page will hopefully make you more productive at doing just that. It is based on my experience of using GNU Emacs as a development environment for C and syntactically similar languages since 1997. I'm assuming you use a relatively recent GNU Emacs (preferably version 21.x) on a UNIX-like machine. Most of my tips will probably also work in XEmacs in some other development environment, but your mileage may vary.

Preliminaries

You should add any customization code to your ~/.emacs. If you're doing any C customization at all, add a 
(require 'cc-mode)
to your ~/.emacs. If you'd like syntax colorization, add a 
(global-font-lock-mode 1)
to your ~/.emacs.

Compiling/linking your project

Emacs makes it easy to get your project to build, by providing a means to move the cursor (known as the "point" in emacs) to the locus of compilation errors. Simply run M-x compile, and then type in the name of your compilation command (this is probably "make" or something similar). If there are any errors, you can press the key sequence C-x ` to visit the first error found. You can then press C-x ` again to visit the second error found, etc. To re-start the sequence of visiting errors (i.e. to visit the first one again), use the key sequence C-u C-x ` which will take you back to the first error. At one point, I got tired of typing M-x compile, so I bound it to a key, in particular F9 (Borland JBuilder trained me that this key is for building and also keys F5-F9 are user-assignable in emacs). Here's how I did that: 
(global-set-key [(f9)] 'compile)
Now, pressing F9 ENTER starts a build. Or, you can adjust the build command in between pressing F9 and ENTER.

Better management of the compilation window

I don't like it that the compilation window takes up 1/2 of the frame by default. So, I use the following, which works well most of the time: 
(setq compilation-window-height 8)
I also don't like that the compilation window sticks around after a successful compile. After all, most of the time, all I care about is that the compile completed cleanly. Here's how I make the compilation window go away, only if there was no compilation errors: 
(setq compilation-finish-function
   (lambda (buf str)

     (if (string-match "exited abnormally" str)

         ;;there were errors
         (message "compilation errors, press C-x ` to visit")

       ;;no errors, make the compilation window go away in 0.5 seconds
       (run-at-time 0.5 nil 'delete-windows-on buf)
       (message "NO COMPILATION ERRORS!"))))

Enabling hungry delete

Simply add the line (c-toggle-hungry-state 1) to your ~/.emacs, and you will enable "hungry" delete, which means that all whitespace around the cursor will be consumed when you press Backspace or C-d. Try it out, it will probably save you some keystrokes.

Tabs vs. spaces for indentation

It's easy to indent or re-indent current lines when doing C development, just press the TAB key. The problem comes when you want to share your code with others. By default, emacs uses a mixture of tabs and spaces for indentation, since tabs save bytes (by representing multiple units of indentation with a single byte), and spaces are important for alignment. Not all editors use this strategy however, and may barf on code that is indented using this strategy. I personally like to use all-spaces for indentation and no TABs, but sometimes it's not your call how to indent your files. Here's how to play nicely with e.g coworkers who use different editors.

If you need to use only TABs for indentation

You can achieve this in C/C++/java modes with the following in your ~/.emacs: 
(require 'cc-mode)
(defun my-build-tab-stop-list (width)
(let ((num-tab-stops (/ 80 width))
 (counter 1)
 (ls nil))
 (while (<= counter num-tab-stops)
   (setq ls (cons (* width counter) ls))
   (setq counter (1+ counter)))
 (set (make-local-variable 'tab-stop-list) (nreverse ls))))
(defun my-c-mode-common-hook ()
(setq tab-width 5) ;; change this to taste, this is what K&R uses :)
(my-build-tab-stop-list tab-width)
(setq c-basic-offset tab-width))
(add-hook 'c-mode-common-hook 'my-c-mode-common-hook)
By redefining the tab-stop-list in each C (or similar) buffer inside a hook which will be executed as each C buffer is opened, indentations should arrive at tab stops, obviating the need for space-padding of any kind. This will not work correctly, however, if you are trying to lineup arglists, etc. (e.g. (c-set-offset 'arglist-cont-nonempty 'c-lineup-arglist)). That's a fundamental problem...how do you align code with TABS to arbitrary columns, without using spaces? Therefore, I recommend using only spaces for indentation instead...

If you need to use only spaces for indentation

You can achieve this in C/C++/java modes with the following in your ~/.emacs: 
(require 'cc-mode)
(defun my-build-tab-stop-list (width)
(let ((num-tab-stops (/ 80 width))
 (counter 1)
 (ls nil))
 (while (<= counter num-tab-stops)
   (setq ls (cons (* width counter) ls))
   (setq counter (1+ counter)))
 (set (make-local-variable 'tab-stop-list) (nreverse ls))))
(defun my-c-mode-common-hook ()
(setq tab-width 5) ;; change this to taste, this is what K&R uses :)
(my-build-tab-stop-list tab-width)
(setq c-basic-offset tab-width)
(setq indent-tabs-mode nil)) ;; force only spaces for indentation
(add-hook 'c-mode-common-hook 'my-c-mode-common-hook)
By adding the line with the comment "force only spaces for indentation" to the earlier example, all indentations of new C code will use spaces for indentation. This will make life easier, as your code will look the same in all editors and you can explore using spaces for lining up argument lists, etc.

Customizing indentation

First of all, put (require 'cc-mode) atop the C customization section of your ~/.emacs, so the methods below will be defined. Then, while visiting a C source file, if you don't like how a particular line is indenting, press C-c C-o near the expression you want to change, and figure out the symbol to change (pressing C-c C-o gives you a chance to set these variables interactively). Then, do a (c-set-offset 'symbol-to-change X) in your ~/.emacs where X is typically a numeric value or the symbol '+ or '-. The following is an example of some of my customizations, which is simply my personal preference: 
;; personal preferences
(c-set-offset 'substatement-open 0)
(c-set-offset 'case-label '+)
(c-set-offset 'arglist-cont-nonempty '+)
(c-set-offset 'arglist-intro '+)
(c-set-offset 'topmost-intro-cont '+)

Debugging in emacs

M-x gdb (or M-x jdb) is very useful to debug inside emacs. Try it, it will split your frame into two windows, with the gdb interaction buffer in the top window and the current source line (if the program is being executed) displayed in the bottom window. I typically use the following sequence:
  1. type M-x gdb. Enter the executable name to run, e.g. ./foobar
  2. in the gdb interaction buffer, type "break main" and "run"
  3. to use the debugger to execute the current statement and go to the next one, use C-c C-n
  4. to use the debugger to step into the current statement, use C-c C-s
You can still use all the power of gdb that you could from any shell prompt, but the arrow following the current source line is value added by emacs, providing debugger state without requiring a lot of gdb list statements.

Indexing your source code for easy navigation

Emacs comes with an etags executable (and also probably its cousin ctags), which can index source code, allowing you to jump around your source code quickly by simply giving a method name to jump to, etc. Here are some simple steps to get you started:
  1. from a shell, run etags *.[ch] in your source directory, which will index or re-index the .c and .h files in your source directory, and will create a file named TAGS.
  2. inside emacs, run M-x visit-tags-table RET and then enter the name of the TAGS file created by the previous step.
  3. for example, to visit a function named "sortRecords", type M-. and then enter the name "sortRecords". Or, better yet, enter just "sortRec", as substrings will work as well, as long as they are unique.
  4. did your press of M-. not put you in the right function/variable? Then try pressing C-u M-. to visit the next function/variable with a similar name.
  5. do you want to go back to where you were before the last M-. or C-u M-.? Then simply to M-*, each press of which will pop a stack and return you to where you came from.

item.title: Innovation
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded:
The caravel, developed by Iberian ship makers, combined all the advantages of the northern European round ship with all the advantages of the southern European round ship.
Because the great innovation of caravel, which, like all great innovations, seems blindingly obvious in hindsight, was to use both square sails and lateen sails on a single sailing ship.
You will have one large square sail so that you can go fast when the wind is in your back. But you will also have triangular lateen sails on board so that when the wind is against you and you need to tack into the wind, as you must do if have any hope of coming back up the coast of west Africa, well now you can do that as well. And it was the combination of different types of sails that made the caravel so uniquely useful for exploration in the fifteen century.
-- Philip Daileader

What General Weygand called the Battle of France is over. I expect that the Battle of Britain is about to begin. Upon this battle depends the survival of Christian civilization. Upon it depends our own British life, and the long continuity of our institutions and our Empire. The whole fury and might of the enemy must very soon be turned on us.
Hitler knows that he will have to break us in this Island or lose the war. If we can stand up to him, all Europe may be free and the life of the world may move forward into broad, sunlit uplands. But if we fail, then the whole world, including the United States, including all that we have known and cared for, will sink into the abyss of a new Dark Age made more sinister, and perhaps more protracted, by the lights of perverted science.
Let us therefore brace ourselves to our duties, and so bear ourselves that if the British Empire and its Commonwealth last for a thousand years, men will still say, 'This was their finest hour.'

item.title: Tacitus on Freedom
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded: And in this Life of Agricola, Tacitus passes his own judgement on "this empire for which we have sacrificed so much". "We gave up freedom in order to maintain our empire" is what Tacitus says. "We accepted the Caesar because he could keep our empire. We thought that more important. But what is our empire?" And he allows a chieftain of the Caledonians, in a land we call Scotland today, to speak out right before the climatic battle with Agricola. Calgacus is the chieftain's name: "The Romans are but robbers and plunderers. And their empire is nothing more than organized plunder. They come to reduce the world to slavery. If it is rich enough, an area, they will conquer it for its plunder. And if it is poor like us, they conquer it just out of the lust for power.Â  They have reduced the Gauls to slavery. They want to reduce the Germans to slavery. And now they have come to the end of the Earth, a land so alien to them, just out of their lust for power. They make a desert and they call it peace." That is not Calgacus. That is Tacitus speaking on an empire that is corrupt and without meaning. And then in his greatest work, his Annals, he describes the origin of this empire: "People have been afraid", he said, "up until now, to write about the origins of this system of Augustus. I write without partisanship or anger. I simply tell you how it was. And I tell you about Augustus." He does it without repeating the same moral judgements over and over again. He lets the deeds of Augustus speak for him. How Augustus won over the soldiers by gifts, the people with cheap bread, and everybody with the repose of peace. He set up what he called the Principate, but was in fact an imperial monarchy - ruled in hypocrisy, founded in fraud and violence. He was himself, Augustus, the arch-hypocrite. "And we accepted his system because we were no longer worthy of freedom. We were no longer morally worthy of it. So can we be surprised when he dies we get a monster like Tiberius, a lunatic like Caligula, a fool like Claudius, or a vicious buffoon like Nero?" "Once we step through the Tyrant's door, once we accepted its security over liberty, then our choices were gone." - J. Rufus Fears

item.title: Florentine Bank Industry and the English Crown
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded:
Even before the plague hit, weaknesses in the Florentine economy had been evident. In 1338, two giant banking firms, the Bardi and Peruzzi, had collapsed.
The Bardi and Peruzi were arms of wool companies, and they did Â most of their business in London, where they provided banking functions to enable their companies to buy English raw wool and ship it to Florence for manufacture into cloth. The cloth was then often re-shipped to London for sale.
Both banks had gotten into the partice of making loans to the English crown. When King Edward III became involved in the extremely expensive Hundred Years War, the status of these loans became shaky, and before long, the king defaulted. Both banks immediately collapsed.
The collapse sent shock waves through the Florentine economy and raised questions about the structure of the banking industry.
-- Andrew C. Fix

item.title: The Warrior Pope and the Church on the Eve of Reformation
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded:
Having gone through the horrors of the Babylonian Captivity and the Great Schism and having just re-conquered most of the Papal States, popes focused on ruling the church and their secular domain rather than on the task of spiritual leadership. They became immersed in Italian and European politics, were always in search of revenue, and became patrons of the arts and humanism, just like other rulers.
Pope Sixus IV (1414-1484) spent hisÂ time on re-conquering the remaining Papal States, and he put his relatives in charge of them.
Pope Alexander VI (1431-1503) used bribes to secure his election, then moved into the Vatican with his wife and seven children. While there, he had a child with his daughter Lucretia. The pope was accused of poisoning many of his opponents, and he himself died this way.
Pope Julius II (1443-1513) was known asÂ the warrior pope. Â He fought wars with major European powers such as France, Spain, Venice and other powers. The thing that is different about Julius is that he didn't fight these wars behind the scenes or from the Vatican. He got on horse, and dressed up armors, got his sword out and led the army in person... Apparently he was more of a gifted military man than he was in anything else.
Pope Clement VII and Pope Leo X, who reigned in the 1520s, were both sons of the house of Medici. They had all the political interests of the Medicis, helping the family back to power in Florence after the fall of Soderini. They were patrons of the arts and learning, true Renaissance princes. The built a new St. Peter's Cathedral in Rome and patronized Raphael and Michelangelo. Meanwhile, it was during their reigns that Martin Luther and the Reformation appeared in Germany.
- Andrew C. Fix

item.title: The Fall of Carthage
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded:
Scipio, when he looked upon the city as it was utterly perishing and in the last throes of its complete destruction, is said to have shed tears and wept openly for his enemies. After being wrapped in thought for long, and realizing that all cities, nations, and authorities must, like men, meet their doom; that this happened toÂ Ilium, once a prosperous city, to the empires ofÂ Assyria,Â Media, andÂ Persia, the greatest of their time, and toÂ MacedoniaÂ itself, the brilliance of which was so recent, either deliberately or the verses escaping him, he said:

A day will come when sacred Troy shall perish, AndÂ PriamÂ and his people shall be slain.

And whenÂ PolybiusÂ speaking with freedom to him, for he was his teacher, asked him what he meant by the words, they say that without any attempt at concealment he named his own country, for which he feared when he reflected on the fate of all things human. Polybius actually heard him and recalls it in his history.

- Polybius

item.title: Dutch Dikes
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded:
The Spanish were now ready to penetrate the heart of rebellious Holland. But the city of Alkmaar had to be attacked first so as not to leave hostile forces in the rear of the Spanish army. The city was besieged and near defeat when the Dutch breached the dikes surrounding the city, flooding the countryside and forcing the Spanish to retire. The revolt was saved for now. The Dutch have a saying "It is from Alkmaar that victory dates."
The Spanish army never made such a serious invasion into the north again, and the big rivers and dikes were a major reason.
On one occasion in 1575, when a Spanish force was besieging the town of Leiden, William of Orange ordered the dikes opened, then sailed a small fleet across what had been farmland to relieve the city.
...
Louis's armies then invaded Netherlands, and have tremendous success initially againstÂ the Dutch who don't have a particular large army.
Things are looking very bad for the Dutch. Louis captures Utrecht, he approaches Amsterdam. AndÂ he's on the verge of complete victory over the Netherlands, when the Dutch open the dikes, flood the countryside, and basically washes Louis's army away - the same way they had washed the Spanish armies away, out side of Alkmaar, and Leiden during the Dutch Revolt.
So once again, Louis's unsuccessful. he's lostÂ his second war.
-- Andrew C. Fix

item.title: Paine's Common Sense
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded: Under our present denomination of British subjects we can neither be received nor heard abroad: The custom of all courts is against us, and will be so, until, by an independence, we take rank with other nations. These proceedings may at firstÂ appear strange and difficult; but, like all other steps which we have already passed over, will in a little time become familiar and agreeable; and, until an independence is declared, the Continent will feel itself like a man who continues putting off some unpleasant business from day to day, yet knows it must be done, hates to set about it, wishes it over, and is continually haunted by the thoughts of its necessity. -- Thomas Paine

item.title: Ethos and Pathos
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded:
What goes wrong with these emails fromÂ unknown sources?
Among a whole list of things are wrong with them, but one thing that goes wrong is that they are heavy on the Pathos, but light on Ethos.
There's nothing intrinsically ethically or morally problematic with just simple Pathos-based appeals. But as a general rule, attempts to persuade are much more successful when they combine Pathos and Ethos. And usually they are successful if they emphasize the Ethos instead of the Pathos.
You can give me the most pathetic, in the kind of classical, rhetorical sense of the word, Â the most pathetic argument ever. But if I don't trust the Ethos, it's not gonna get you very far.
-- Â Dorsey Armstrong

item.title: The Power of Words
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded:
If you really want to be an astute, engaged reader and writer, then my best piece of advice would be: Be promiscuous--read everything you can; write whenever you can. You can make yourself a beautiful space in which to write. Write with a pen or a pencil, on the computer, on the back of an envelope. Read everything you can--editorials, short stories, histories, biographies, novels, poems, plays. The world around us is filled with words; take in as many as you can, and then give us some back.
-- Dorsey Armstrong

item.title: Argument as a way of knowing
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded:
Argumentation is also a way of knowing. The pragmatist philosopher Charles Peirce identified four ways of knowing. Tenacity is the method of chance; one sticks to the first belief one gets. Authority involves the uncritical acceptance of a prominent person's beliefs. A priori correspondence means that beliefs are deduced from self-evident premises. Verification is the method of science. Verification has advantages over the other three methods. It is open to public inspection. It can be replicated by others. Results are obtained by design rather than by accident. But if verification were the only acceptable path to knowledge, then we would be unable to know about some of the topics that concern us most. There would be no way to know about values, probabilities, predictions, or recommendations for action. The alternative is to look for analogues that achieve many of the same purpose as verification and that apply to these topics. Argumentation is such an analogue.
  • There is mutual agreement on the procedures to be followed.
  • The norms of candor and sincerity are shared.
  • Reflective judgment is the goal.
  • The knowledge that one's views may be challenged creates an incentive to search for arguments of high quality.
The view that argumentation is a way of knowing has two important corollaries. In the realm of the uncertain, truth is relative to the argument that is advanced for it. We know through interaction with others; if the self is a composite of what we know, it is developed through interaction with others. -- David Zarefsky

item.title: Argument and Free Society
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded:
Trust in the power of reason was shattered during the early 20th century. Social science dealt more with empirical realities than with normative claims. Freudian psychology emphasized unconscious motivation. Crowd psychology focused on how people behave differently when they are grouped together. Disillusionment that followed World War I fueled awareness of the power of propaganda.
During the 1920s, it became fashionable to argue against the competence of public judgment. Walter Lippmann, for example, maintained that public opinion had been disastrously wrong at the critical junctures of history. The reason, he claimed, was a commitment to the false ideal of the competent citizen.
More recently, Lippmann and others have suggested that it is possible to cultivate a "public philosophy" that reinstates the place of reason in civic discussion. The public philosophy requires awareness Â of society's social knowledge. It requires advocates who are able to "stand in" for the public and speak on its behalf. Making claims on behalf of the public demands that the advocate make strong claims and defend them ably. Training in argumentation helps one to prevent weak claims from triumphing over strong ones. Argumentation legitimizes freedom of speech and, thereby, permits a free society to function.
â David Zarefsky

item.title: Argumentation and Ethic
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded:
Ethical considerations figure prominently in argumentation. Any attempt to influence other people raises ethical issues. It is a limitation on freedom of choice. It is the application of superior to inferior force. But argumentation seeks to achieve ethical influence. It does not influence people against their will but seeks their free assent. Without influence, the conditions of society and community are not possible. Argumentation respects different ways of thinking and reasoning.
â David Zarefsky

item.title: Perception and Internal Models
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded: Humans are not in direct contact with the external world but pick up cues as to what is in the external world and form models from these cues. Because this process is so automatic, we need to be reminded of this fact through parables and perceptual illusions. One reason our internal models are different from the external world is that we have sensory limitations. For example, we are tuned to only a small part of the electromagnetic frequency spectrum, which we egocentrically call light. Imagine if someone turned on the rest of the spectrum, so that you now saw infrared light, ultraviolet light, radio waves, and microwaves, and you were experiencing all radio stations, TV stations, cell phone calls, and so on at the same time. Likewise for sound, we are sensitive to sound waves only in the 20,000-Hz to 200-Hz range. We do not hear dog whistles, bat radar, and similar sounds. For smell, we can pick up only some of the chemicals floating around in the air; egocentrically, we say that the rest are odorless. We are good at picking up rather subtle cues to form our internal models. When there are ambiguous cues, we can entertain more than one internal model, and our active perceptual system can alternate these models, overriding our consciousÂ control. In some cases, our internal models are not in correspondence with external reality, and we see visual illusions, such as lines of different lengths when the lines are equal, squares of different grey shades when the shades are the same, and curved lines when lines are straight. [caption id="attachment_965" align="alignright" width="480"] Muller-Lyer Illusion[/caption]   -- David W. Martin

item.title: The Naked Ape
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded:
Mammals evolved about 200 million years ago, and about 85 million years ago, some of these evolved into primates.Â These primates lived largely in the forests and probably led a nomadic life, moving as food supplies were depleted. About 35 million years ago, apes evolved. About 10 million years ago, the forest began to disappear and our ancestors had to change in ways that allowed them to compete successfully with the plains animals that were highly evolved to fit that environment. Between 5 and 4 million years ago, our ancestors evolved the ability to walk on two legs; among the many reasons why this adaptation might have been advantageous is to free up the hands. During the evolution of our ancestors, many changes apparently took place to make them competitive with the plains animals.
  • One important change is called neoteny, the process by which birth occurs much earlier in the development of the organism, allowing the brain and behavior to develop according to the requirements of the environment.
  • The brain size increased markedly.
  • Pair bonding of a man and woman also had to develop in order to rear the inept offspring.
  • As meat replaced some of the vegetarian diet, cooperative hunting by the men was required.
  • The nomadic way of life was also apparently replaced with a territorial existence.
In his 1967 book The Naked Ape, Desmond Morris emphasizes several adaptations that must have taken place within the context of the evolution of humans. He asks the question:" Why are we the only naked [relatively] ape?"
  • There are several hypothesized possibilities, including problems with cleanliness and even possibly diseases carried by fleas.
  • Another possibility is that nakedness led to more satisfying sex.
  • A third possibility is that there was an aquatic phase during which fur would have been problematic.
  • The most widely accepted version is that the loss of hair led to our ancestor's ability to cool down as they engaged in the long-distance running required to chase down game during hunting.
Although our ancestors couldn't fast, humans can outrun almost all other animals, includingÂ animals even like horses. Again, not very fast, takes them a lot time to do it, but humans run long distances. That's probably how our ancestors hunted. But again, they can't do that with a fur coat. Morris also asks why we are the sexiest of the apes.
  • He suggests that although sex is, of course, necessary for reproduction, the vast majority of sex engaged in by humans occurs when impregnation is not possible; thus, it must be for the purpose of holding the pair bond together.
  • The development of many physical features, such as breasts, lips and earlobes, along with face-to-face sex, led to enhanced sex pleasure.
  • Behavioral changes also led to a strengthening of the pair bond, such as the constant receptivity of women and the privacy of the sex act.
However, problems come about today because of a mismatch of our current environment with evolved tendencies, such as the constant exposure of men and women to members of the opposite sex who give off strong evolved sexual signals. Morris also asks why modern humans have used aggression to push themselves to the brink of annihilation.
  • He suggests that aggression, particularly for animals with strong male competition, is inevitable.
  • However, in animals with killing weapons, such as teeth and claws, as the killing weapons evolved, there also evolved behavioral inhibitions about using these weapons on member of their own species.
  • In humans, our most effective killing weapons are products of technology rather than evolution, and the time span during which they were developed is far too short for behavioral inhibitions against their use to have evolved.
-- David W. Martin

item.title: Life, An Evolutionary Psychology Perspective
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded: Darwin had a difficult time explaining altruistic behavior because, by definition, that behavior puts an individual's survival at risk without reproductive gain. However, William Hamilton put more emphasis on the survival of the genetic material. In this case, individual is just a temporary life-support system that the genetic material lives in while it tries to replicate itself in order to become immortal. Hamilton proposed that some altruistic behavior is the result of inclusive fitness, that is, behaving in ways that improve the survival and reproduction of all our relatives, not just our children. Support for Hamilton's rule, formula 'c < rb'--we will act if the cost to ourselves is less than our relatedness to the other person times the benefit to the other person--is found in research on the warning behavior of ground squirrels, human wills, and human helping behavior. Differential parental investment, the much greater time, effort, and resources devoted by the woman to a child, helps explain the different mating strategies of men and women. Men have a mixed strategy of both trying to impregnate as many woman as possible and establishÂ a more permanent relationship with a high-quality mate and devoting resources to the resulting offspring. Women primarily follow the latter strategy. The differences in these strategies predicts the findings of much research, including the fact that men are much more agreeable to casual sex, desire sex with more partners, are more upset by sexual infidelity than romantic infidelity, and more interested in fertility, as exemplified by youth and physical beauty, and less interested in financial prospects of mates than are women. Evolutionary psychology can also help explain some of the problems with aggression, parenting, and overeating in today's world. Men are by far the deadlier sex in terms of both homicides and wars. Because of competition for reproductive women, men's genes have predisposed them to be aggressive and take more risks. As predicted by the theory, unmarried and unemployed men, particularly those in their prime reproductive years, are the most likely to kill other men or be killed by them. Men kill other men because if status or jealous and kill women because of suspected infidelity. Women's aggression tends to take the form of verbal derogation of rivals. Men exclusively engage in war by forming cooperative alliances to attain the resources for sexual reproduction. Some of the conflicts in families can be explained by considering the relatedness of the various parties. The majority of parenting is done by mothers, perhaps because fathers are uncertain of their fatherhood or because they want to devote resources to other mating opportunities. As predicted by evolutionary theory, step fathers are much more likely to abuse or kill stepchildren than biologically related children, particularly when the children are young. The fact that our population is increasingly overweight can be partially attributed to our bodies' tendency to adjust metabolic levels to maintain weight and to our built-in tasteÂ for foods that we can store on our bodies in the form of fat. In addition, our ancestors gave us an aversion to unnecessary exercise. The unhealthy mismatch of our built-in tendencies with the current environment is an example of the naturalistic fallacy. -- David W. Martin

item.title: The Idea Of Gentlemen Amateur And The Decline of The British Empire
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded:
By the late 19 century, the highestÂ award in British life didn't go to the industrialists. They went instead to the gentlemen. And the idea of the gentlemen amateur was corrosive to British industrial supremacy. In America, to say someone is professional isÂ meant to be high praise. It suggests they do a job and they do it very well indeed. But in Britain, the highest praise is reservedÂ for the amateur: somebody who does something simply because their love of it. In British life, the most prestigious job you could have was to not have a job at all. Leisure was a higher status than hard work.Â What that meant was that it was relatively unusual for industrial dynasties to develop inside British life. Whereas in America, you gotÂ families like the Vanderbilt, where one generation after the next, Â each one builds on the achievements of the previous one. What tended to happen in Britain isÂ that a manÂ made a fortune in industry, would then sent his son to Eton, and then to Oxford and Cambridge. And thereÂ the ethos was very much one of learning how to be a leisured gentlemen. And very often, the sons trained in that way, Â would spend the money they inherited from their fathers to buy their way into the landed classes, rather than remaining committed to industrialization, whose social prestige was comparatively lower. However, a social situation which is in someway attractive does carry costs. You could imagine that if people are moving out of industry into the leisured landed classes, Â rather than reinvesting everything in the factory, sooner or later they are goingÂ to get left behind. Especially they are up against American competitors, or German competitors, who have different ideas about what carries status and prestige. By 1900, the British empire started to become a place in which the British would shelter behind their relatively inefficient industrial system. As they started to lose ground, they started to use the empire to compensate. Here is the historian Paul Johnson. He says:
... it is not surprising that the English, confronted by growing evidence that they were no longer the world's leading industrial power, sought redress and relief not in an economic solution but in a political one. They did not use the State to become more efficient. They used the State to enlarge the area in which their inefficiency would matter less. In short, they invented modern imperialism. This was, or at any rate seemed to be, the easy way out. But it was a choice directed not by strength but by weakness. Unable to compete successfully in the developed markets, the English turned to a further exploitation and enlargement of their sphere of influence in the backward parts of the world.
And that was a prelude to the return toÂ protectionism and the creation of a free trade area within the empire, while trying to keep the Germans and Americans out. But of course, once the colonies got self-government, that internal wasÂ going toÂ be difficult. Because the politician in the newly independent colonies would necessarily be tempted to find trading with Americans, where the commodities cost less, the more of better quality, more attractive, than holding on to trade with Britain. -- Patrick Allitt

item.title: Risk, Return and Diversification
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded:
Everyone seems to think that as you bear more risk, you'll earn a higher return, but this really isn't true. In fact, it's an oversimplification of the true relationship between risk and return. The truth is that some risks, called systematic risks, are highly rewarded while others, called idiosyncratic risks, are worth nothing.
The actual return on an investment is the sum of the expected return and the unexpected return:
R_i = E_i + U_i,
where R is the actual return, E is the expected return, U is the unexpected return, and the subscript i references the type of asset that this is. The unexpected return could be positive or negative.
What is risk? In this framework, risk is getting a negative value for the unexpected return, U.
Now, let's introduce diversification: the practice of investing in several or many different assets rather than only one or a few assets.
Diversification isn't just about making sure that you limit your total loss by spreading out the risk; it actually reduces risk.Â For example, if the actual return is R_i = E_i + U_i and you only have one asset-- asset 1--then the actual return is going to fully reflect both the expected return and the unexpected return on asset 1.
However, what if you added another asset, asset 2, to your investment portfolio? If you assume that 1/2 of your savings are invested in each asset, then you can calculate the total return to your portfolio by adding the returns of both assets and dividing by 2. Then, your total return is given by this equation:
portfolio return = 1/2 * (R_1 + R_2) = 1/2 * (E_1 + E_2) + 1/2 * (U_1 + U_2),
where U_1 and U_2 are the unexpected returns from each asset.
Each unexpected return may be positive or negative, or one may be positive and the other may be negative. When one is positive and the other is negative, then they tend to cancel each other out--at least a little.
In short, the more assets you add, the more offsetting of unexpected returns you'll get.
However, there is a limit to diversification. Â Even if you have the most well-diversified portfolio, you will still experience unexpected returns because diversification reduces risk but can't eliminate it.
The type of risk that diversification reduces, through this cancelation process, is called idiosyncratic risk, which is a risk that is specific to each particular asset and doesn't share anything in common with any other assets--it's not correlated across assets. When we increase the number of assets in a portfolio, we expect that, on average, the idiosyncratic risks will cancel each other out--that the actual return will get closer to the expected return.
The other type of risk in the unexpected return is called systematic risk, which is a risk that is common across assets--meaning that when this risk creates a positive unexpected return in oneÂ asset, it's doing the same thing to all other risky assets. Systematic risk is risk that you can't get rid of through diversification.
Economists still can't quite agree on what causes systematic risk. There are many ideas, but they all seem to be similar. Most theories about the sources of systematic risk involve risks to the overall economy, to the financial markets, or to both.
Economists know that people are risk averse, but if you compensate them, they'll bear it. Additionally, if there's a risk that they have to pay to get rid of, they'll probably put up with at least some of it. However, if there is a risk that we can get rid of for free, no risk-averse person would pass up the chance to eliminate that risk.
Diversification gets rid of idiosyncratic risk, and you don't have to pay extra to diversify your portfolio, especially if you choose a prediversified asset like a mutual fund. Therefore, there's no reason to expect compensation for bearing idiosyncratic risk.
System risk is the risk that you can't get rid of, so in order to induce a risk-averse person to hold an asset with systematic risk, they have to be compensated for that. The compensation comes in the form of a higher expected return from holding that asset--relative to an asset with no systematic risk.
The relationship between risk and return is that higher systematic risk leads to higher expected return. You only get paid to hold systematic risk, not all risk, and you can only expect to get paid--you won't necessarily get all the compensation you demand. Of course, if you hold the asset long enough, then your actual compensation should come close to the expected return.
There are many different theories about what determines investment returns, but they all agree that idiosyncratic risk is worthless while systematic risk is compensated. Furthermore, they all agree that any asset that has no systematic risk should earn the risk-free rate of return--the return on a government bond. Even an asset with a highly risky return should only earn the risk-free rate on average, if all the risk is idiosyncratic risk.
-- Connel Fullenkamp

item.title: Ulysses's Speech on the Arms of Achilles
item.dc:creator: mengqi
item.content:encoded: ... You weren't alone when you bore your shield in defense of the allied fleet; a crowd was behind you, while only one person accompanied me. If he wasn't aware that fighters come lower than thinkers and prizes aren't owed to a strong right arm, however unflinching, he'd claim those weapons himself, and so would Ajax the lesser, warlike Eurypylus, Thoas the son of the famous Andraemon; so would Idomeneus, Meriones his companion from Crete, and royal Agamemnon's younger brother, the brave Menelaus. Of course they are sturdy warriors, fully my equals in battle - but not in the tactics of warfare. Your physical might serves well on the filed, but your limited powers of thinking need my direction. Your strength is mindless, where my concern is to plan ahead. You surely can fight, but it's I who advises the king when he's choosing the critical moment for action. Your simple brawn must be measured against my brains. In a ship the helmsman take precedence over the rower; in war the commander has more respect than the soldier; so I must rank above you.Â In the make-up of human beings, intelligence counts for more than our hands, and that is our true strength. 'Princes of Greece, I call on you now to reward your watchman. Reward me for all those years of anxious and careful devotion. I ask you to give me the prize which I'm owed for my dutiful service. Â My work is complete: by removing obstacle fate had imposed, by enabling the capture of Illium's towers, I achieved their capture. By all the hopes that we share by the toppling defenses of Troy, in the name of the gods whose aid I recently stole from the foe, by anything yet to be done where intelligent action is needed, remember Ulysses! Or else, If it cannot be mine, let this armor be hers!' - and he pointed towards the fateful image of Pallas. - Ovid, <Metamorphoses> [caption id="attachment_1022" align="alignright" width="1024"] Ajax andÂ Ulysses disputeÂ theÂ armsÂ of Achilles[/caption]
